description: Eczema, also known as atopic dermatitis, is a long-term (chronic) skin condition that causes dry, itchy patches of skin.
It's a common condition, particularly in children, and can range in severity from mild to severe.
most_likely_cause_of_disease: The exact cause is unknown, but it's believed to be a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
A weakened skin barrier, which allows irritants and allergens to enter the skin more easily.
A faulty immune system, which may overreact to triggers.
Dry skin, which is more prone to irritation and inflammation.
Exposure to allergens, such as dust mites, pollen, pet dander, and certain foods.
Irritants, such as soaps, detergents, and perfumes.
precautions_we_need_to_take: Avoid known triggers, such as allergens and irritants.
Keep skin moisturized by applying a thick, fragrance-free moisturizer regularly.
Take lukewarm baths or showers and avoid harsh soaps.
Avoid scratching, as this can worsen inflammation.
Use cool compresses to relieve itching.
symptoms_of_that_disease: Skin infections, such as impetigo or cellulitis.
diet_we_need_to_follow: There is no specific diet for eczema, but some people may find that certain foods worsen their symptoms.
Common food triggers include dairy products, eggs, wheat, soy, nuts, and seafood.
It's important to keep a food diary to track potential triggers.
A balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains is generally recommended.
Staying hydrated by drinking plenty of water is also important.
Probiotics, which are good bacteria found in fermented foods, may help to improve gut health and reduce eczema symptoms.
affect_of_disease: Eczema can be uncomfortable and itchy, affecting quality of life.
It can lead to skin infections.
In severe cases, it can cause sleep disturbances and emotional distress.
There is no cure for eczema, but treatments can help to manage symptoms and improve quality of life.
